Now thou art free from me. Remember that thou hast not so much escaped from sway, as rather passed be- neath that of another. Shouldst thou behave not as thou oughtest towards thy husband, he in my stead shall admonish thee with this rod.” With this the father, concluding his speech, stretches at the same time the whip to the bridegroom, who excusing him- self briefly according to custom, says that he “be- lieves he shall have no need of this whip '⁵3 but he is bound to accept it, and put it up under his belt, like a valuable present. “

Now, towards the evening which precedes the solemn nuptials, the bride is conducted by her mother and other matrons in a carriage, or, if it should be winter, in a sledge, with her marriage trousseaa and a nuptial bed, elegantly appareled, to the bride- groom’s house, and there she is guarded over-night, so that she may not be seen by her husband.
